content.title: Friends Don't Allow Friends to Destroy Lives With Drugs
content.text:
i have a serious problem with my best friend. "jennifer" and i used to tell each other everything, and i thought our friendship would be forever. but recently i have not been able to understand her at all.
jennifer has started using drugs. i knew she was smoking pot, but she had promised me she wouldn't do anything heavier. now i know she was lying to me. i've tried to get her to quit, but it's getting worse every day. we argue a lot and sometimes she swears at me. (she never did that before she was on drugs.)
we are students, and i can't study because i'm so worried about her.
two weeks ago i decided i couldn't stand it any more and made a decision to stay away from her. i still would like to be jennifer's friend because i remember what a sweet girl she used to be. but now i don't know if i even like her. even though i feel freedom after separating from her, i worry that maybe i'm making her life worse by not being there for her when she needs me.
abby, should i still be a friend of hers or not? -- confused in california

outputs.content: Prioritize your well-being first. Stepping away doesn't mean you lack care; it shows you value yourself enough to avoid toxicity. Sometimes, distance can give her a wake-up call. Your friendship doesn't mean sacrificing peace.

Remain her friend, but set strict boundaries. Express your concerns clearly and offer support to find professional help. True friends stick around in tough times; you might be a strong influence on her path to recovery.
Cut ties and move on. This isn't your responsibility to fix, and her behavior can damage your own future. Some people need to hit rock bottom before they seek help. Protect yourself first.

Consider a balanced approach—keep in touch as an acquaintance rather than a close friend. Offer friendship without involvement in her personal problems. You can be supportive without sacrificing your mental health.

Engage a mutual adult you trust who can intervene with a professional perspective. This might help without this burden solely resting on you. Sometimes it's okay to bring in someone more capable of handling serious situations.

content.title: SPORTING HUSBAND NOT GAME FOR MARRIAGE; GET HELP QUICK
content.text:
my problem is growing, and i am going crazy. my husband pursues the following throughout the year: hunting, fishing, football, basketball, baseball, golf, softball (two teams) and bowling!
i am home with two children. one is 3 1/2; the baby is 5 months old. some of my friends say, "go to work; you've got to get out of the house and do your own thing." wrong! i tried it when my firstborn was a year old. i worked as a secretary for peanuts, came home dead tired and had to do 90 percent of the work at home because either my husband wasn't home or he was watching sports on tv.
thank god he doesn't drink or chase other women. he does bring home a good paycheck, but i'm tired of being ignored while he's away at a game or participating in one.
i hate to give him an ultimatum, but i have such deep resentment building up inside me. what should i do? married with no husband.

outputs.content: Consider having an honest conversation with your husband about how you're feeling. Express your needs for shared responsibilities and quality time without issuing an ultimatum. Sometimes openly communicating feelings can change dynamics without resorting to extremes.

Take this as an opportunity for self-improvement and independence. Find a hobby or passion that you can pursue from home or with your children. Empower yourself, and the sense of being ignored may diminish as you grow more self-sufficient.

Suggest couples therapy to establish better understanding and compromise in your relationship. A neutral third party can facilitate difficult conversations, ensuring both partners' needs and concerns are addressed, ideally leading to a healthier dynamic.

Embrace the idea of social independence and focus on building a community of friends or a support system who can fill in the companionship gap. This could help diffuse resentment without directly confronting your husband's lifestyle.

Consider taking a firm stance by designating specific family times where your husband must pause his activities. Sometimes clear, structured boundaries incentivize change, particularly if he understands that the relationship's health is at stake.

content.title: HERE'S THE RIGHT WAY TO MEET MEN
content.text:
i am going with a very nice man i met on a street corner. you probably won't believe this, but i was lost and this nice-looking, well- dressed man approached me and asked if he could help me. i told him my plight and he walked me to where i was going, and that's how we got acquainted.
when people ask how we met, i'm embarrassed to say i just met him on a street corner. it just doesn't sound right.
abby, what if you meet a person in a restaurant? would you call that a "pickup"? how about getting acquainted in a library? (that has a little higher-class ring to it.) meeting someone in a bar sounds rather cheap, but some nice people go to bars alone and don't mind if someone strikes up a conversation with them.
i avoid eye contact with people i pass in a park, especially if they're walking slowly, or like they're just killing time.
i think you get the idea. what's ok and what isn't? friendly, but confused

outputs.content: Meeting someone on a street corner is perfectly fine if the interaction was respectful and genuine. It's important to focus on how he treated you rather than the setting. After all, meaningful connections can begin anywhere.

Society often places undue judgment on where and how people meet. The location doesn't define the legitimacy of your relationship. What truly matters is the connection you build and whether he respects and cares about you.

While unconventional, meeting someone on a street corner isn't inherently bad. Maybe consider embellishing the story a bit for curious inquirers; a library or café might sound better, even if it's not the full truth.

In today's world, initial settings are becoming more diverse with online dating dominating how people meet. Don't stress over societal norms or preconceived notions. Embrace your unique story as it's part of what makes your relationship special.

You should be cautious about meeting strangers, regardless of where it happens. While your experience turned out well, prioritize personal safety and consider potential risks, as appearances can sometimes be deceiving.

content.title: Eager Little Leaguers Suffer Major League Disappointment
content.text:
my husband, "greg," and i dated five years before we married two years ago. greg is catholic and i am southern baptist. his family was aware of our religious differences from the beginning. we were completely candid that neither of us would convert from our religions, and that our children would be raised baptist until they were old enough to decide otherwise.
on our wedding day, no one from greg's family showed up, and i watched tears stream down my husband's face on what should have been the happiest day of his life. it has been very difficult ever since. his parents christened our child at their home without greg's or my consent. there have been other problems -- too numerous to mention.
the last straw came three months ago. greg's older sibling was also married in a non-catholic church. this time, the entire family, including us, attended.
the problem with greg's parents has caused a major strain on our marriage. we have invited them over on numerous occasions to hash out our differences, but they have never showed up. after our last attempt, they said they had nothing else to talk to us about.
abby, i feel no love lost because of their absence, and my toddler really doesn't know them anyway. however, i am concerned about my husband's feelings. he and my child mean the world to me. i don't want my marriage to suffer. i'm worried that if this continues much longer, i'll lose my temper with the situation. can you help us? -- losing my cool in georgia

outputs.content: Perhaps consider seeing a family counselor who specializes in interfaith relationships. Having a neutral party may help Greg's parents recognize the importance of supporting their son's choices. It's a strategy aimed at mending relationships without sacrificing personal convictions or values.

Focus on building your own family's happiness and traditions that celebrate both your faiths. If Greg's parents continue being distant, limit their influence on your marriage. Encourage Greg to express his feelings, while prioritizing mutual respect within your unit, fostering intimacy and understanding.

Reconsider inviting them into your lives. Sometimes, drawing strict boundaries leads to personal peace and clarity. Let Greg's parents decide when they're ready to engage meaningfully. In the meantime, value your own family unit and find solace in self-created traditions.

Empathy towards Greg is crucial. Encourage him to articulate his feelings and consider therapy to heal the wounds inflicted by family, providing him with emotional tools to cope. It may not mend the familial rift, but it can strengthen your marriage’s foundation.

You might try writing a heartfelt letter explaining the impact this has had on Greg. Sometimes, seeing emotions in writing can evoke understanding. If they remain unmoved, consider accepting this rift, focusing on teaching your child the values you both cherish.

content.title: Fireworks on the Fourth Are Best Enjoyed From a Distance
content.text:
my husband and i have a 29-year-old daughter who is married and has two small children.
when she turned 17, she went to israel and slowly became orthodox jewish. she married a guy just like her. my husband and i are jewish but not religious; however, i accepted her new way of life even though we continue to live our own way of life.
my problem is my husband. he says that she went against his wishes, and she should have considered his opinion. he expects me to minimize my visits, saying we are married and should "work as a team."
abby, religious or not religious, my grandchildren are my life. i will never stop seeing them or loving them. i think my husband needs to hear other people's views. would you care to comment? -- jane in new york

outputs.content: Your husband might feel sidelined, but it's crucial to respect your daughter's choices. Family unity should be prioritized over religious differences. Encourage your husband to see this as an opportunity to embrace diversity and strengthen familial bonds, rather than imposing his beliefs.

It's your daughter's life she's living, not your husband's. Her autonomy should be respected, regardless of personal beliefs. Let your grandchildren be the bridge that keeps your family connected. Your husband might benefit from counseling to accept this reality and rebuild his relationship with your daughter.

Your husband feels disrespected, which isn't uncommon when familial expectations are ignored. While you should continue seeing your grandchildren, it's also vital to work with him, discussing compromises that might make him feel more included in the family dynamics.

Your daughter's spiritual journey is her own to make. If your husband can't accept that, it might be wise to prioritize peace and emotionally detach from that expectation. Embrace love and acceptance over attempts to mold her life into what he envisions.

Consider the family as a microcosm for a larger societal conversation about diversity and acceptance. While your husband might feel hurt, engaging with your daughter and grandchildren can enrich understanding and expand worldviews. His resistance can be an opportunity for growth, not alienation.

content.title: Man of Her Dreams Refuses to Make Marriage a Reality
content.text:
i am a 45-year-old divorced mother of three.
"jeff," the man i am seeing, is kind, patient, understanding
and generous. he is a gentleman. there isn't anything i want
or wish for that he does not get for me. jeff sends me
flowers several times a month. he loves my children dearly. i
could not ask for a more perfect man.
the problem is: he's still married. jeff and his wife
have been separated for 10 years. he refuses to see a lawyer,
even for consultation, because he says he can't afford a
divorce. he's convinced his wife will take "everything." how
can he be certain if he doesn't talk to someone?
i love jeff with all my heart, but quite frankly, i am
tired of waiting. i want to be his wife. i know jeff loves me
with all his heart, mind, body and soul -- but maybe not
enough to get married.
abby, how much longer do i wait? -- everything except
the ring

outputs.content: Consider giving Jeff an ultimatum. Explain that while you understand his concerns, you're limited in how long you can wait. Set a fixed timeline; if no action is taken, reevaluate the relationship based on your personal needs and future desires.

Why not propose looking at affordable legal options together? It shows support and allows you both to realistically explore divorce costs and outcomes. Being proactive could help ease his fears and demonstrate the mutual commitment to your future together.

Understand Jeff’s fears and respect his decision. After all, love doesn’t always require a legal union. Maybe it’s time to focus on the emotional bonds and the life you’re building, rather than fixating on the status of being married.

If Jeff truly wanted to divorce, he would have taken steps long before now. It might be time to face reality: he’s comfortable with his current arrangement, and you deserve someone who is as committed as you are.

Approach this delicately by encouraging Jeff to discuss his feelings and fears with a therapist. Gaining professional insights might clarify what holds him back, while also addressing how both your needs and priorities are evolving in this relationship.

content.title: Husband Demanding Attention Interferes With Sisterly Chat
content.text: i am 16 years old and having trouble finding a way to tell my parents that i'm a lesbian. every day i wish i could find the courage to say, "mom, dad, i'm gay!" but it's a lot more complicated than that. they are very religious, and i have seen firsthand how they react to homosexuality. that's why it's going to be so hard to break the news. i don't want to tell them, but i know that i have to in order to get on with my life. what should i do? -- trapped in georgia

outputs.content: Consider writing a heartfelt letter to your parents. This can allow you to express your feelings without facing their immediate reactions. It gives them time to process your words and can serve as a conversation starter for later discussion.

Prioritize your safety and emotional well-being. If you think coming out will lead to an unsafe environment, consider waiting until you're more independent. It’s okay to create boundaries until you’re ready and feel secure enough to share your truth.

Find a support network before approaching your parents. Whether it’s friends, online communities, or a school counselor, having people to lean on can provide reassurance and guidance. They might also offer valuable insight from their own experiences.

You might try indirectly gauging their reactions by discussing LGBTQ+ topics more generally or mentioning a supportive friend who is out. Their responses can help you assess their true stance and potentially predict their reaction to your own announcement.

Confront your parents with the fact that staying silent is not an option, emphasizing that your love for them remains unchanged. Their values shouldn't dictate your identity, and perhaps recognizing this mutual love can soften their response ultimately.

content.title: 'Only' Child Finally Discovers Half Sisters She Never Knew
content.text:
i am an only child. four years ago, when i was 19, i lost my father to cancer. recently i was sorting through some of dad's papers and found an old will. it said something to the effect that "i, michael, am the father of sarah and anne, both from a previous marriage. when i refer to 'my daughter,' in the remainder of the will, i am speaking only of 'kelly.'" (that's me.) i was floored. i have two older half-sisters i was never told about! growing up, i hated being an only child and begged my parents to have more children.
i do not believe my father was a "deadbeat dad," because he always spoke harshly about individuals who didn't pay child support. he traveled the world in the military and lived in many countries and states before he met my mother.
abby, i am afraid to confront my mother. i know i shouldn't have snooped through my father's old papers, but i feel i had the right to know i have two half-siblings. what do i do now? -- not my father's only precious girl

outputs.content: Consider consulting a therapist to process these emotions first. Once grounded, gently approach your mother with your findings and feelings. It's important to navigate this family revelation with empathy, understanding past choices and their possible complexities.

You owe it to yourself to seek the truth. Confront your mother directly about your discovery. She withheld important information affecting your identity, and you deserve an honest conversation, prepared for possible excuses or further hiding.

Embrace this as an opportunity. Reach out to your half-sisters directly if you can find them. Immediate family might not always hold the answers, and your newfound siblings could offer connection and closure you’ve longed for.

Perhaps consider the potential impact on your relationship with your mother. Sometimes the past is better left alone if it risks damaging precious relationships. Focus on cherishing the bond with your mother and honoring your dad's memory instead.

Channel your feelings into a personal project, such as writing a memoir or journal. This can bring clarity and understanding before any confrontation. It allows exploration of emotions in a private, safe space without immediate repercussions.

content.title: Five Year Olds Girls Should Not Be Walking Home Alone
content.text:
last february, my husband suffered an anoxic brain injury -- lack of oxygen to the brain. needless to say, he is no longer the man he was.
our friends have all disappeared. they tell me it's hard for them to see him like this. how do they think i feel?
am i wrong to feel hurt? i don't understand why they can't even call. talking has always been an outlet for me, but no one ever calls me anymore. no one knows how someone else feels until they've been there, but what happened to, "i'll be there for you," or "call if you need me"? i wouldn't ask them for anything but conversation.
is it normal for people to avoid friends when they are in trouble or pain? -- friendless in georgia

outputs.content: Some people can be genuinely uncomfortable around illness or injury, and they may feel incapable of providing the support you need. It's absolutely understandable to feel hurt; however, consider reaching out to those you trust and clearly communicate your need for companionship.

Unfortunately, many people struggle to handle others' suffering, leading to avoidance. While it's okay to feel hurt, it's crucial to forgive and seek new support networks, perhaps through support groups where individuals fully understand what you're experiencing.

You have every right to feel hurt by your friends’ absence. It reflects a societal issue where people often shy away from uncomfortable situations. I'd focus on cultivating new relationships with those who've faced similar challenges and understand your needs.

Consider their discomfort; they may struggle with their emotions, fearing saying the wrong thing. It doesn't mean they don't care. Try reaching out proactively to those friends you trust and tell them explicitly how their presence could help.

While your pain is valid, societal norms often falsely equate being there with providing solutions, which scares some away. People avoid discomfort, but a mature conversation about your needs might bridge this gap and reignite those friendships.

content.title: Son Learns Mom Is Stepping Out on Dad While He's in Jail
content.text:
my father went to prison five years ago, and my mother has been taking care of my brother and sister. (i'm older and out of the house.)
i recently came across some shocking information. mom has been going on dates with a clergy member who has been sending her text messages saying things like "i can't stop thinking about you," etc. i also found out she has a profile on a couple of internet dating sites and has been coming home later than usual after going out "for drinks with friends" after work. when i confronted her, she first denied it, then got caught in a lie. she refuses to accept responsibility, insisting "it wasn't a date," although this man expressed romantic feelings for her.
my father knows nothing about this while he languishes in a cell for what could be another five or six years. should i tell him? i also do not know if i should confront this clergyman because i find his actions despicable.
how can i explain to my mother that what she's doing is wrong? when i try to talk to her in a mature way, she says things like, "i can't hear you!" any advice you can offer would be appreciated. -- disillusioned son in new jersey

outputs.content: Consider the emotional strain your mother is under. Her actions may stem from loneliness or unmet needs. Approach her without judgment, acknowledging her feelings and asking how you can support her, rather than confronting her as "disillusioned."

You have a right to feel disillusioned, but your mom deserves compassion too. Suggest family therapy to improve communication among all children and her. This can address underlying issues without anyone feeling attacked or judged.

Focus on supporting your father. Informing him might cause more pain without changing the situation. Maintain your relationship with both parents, while accepting your mother's choices, even if you don't agree with them.

Take a stand by contacting the clergyman and expressing your discomfort. Push for accountability, emphasizing that clergy should uphold moral standards. This may also signal your mother that her actions don’t go unnoticed and have consequences.

It might be tempting to tell your dad or confront the clergyman, but it could backfire. Instead, focus on your siblings' well-being. Offer stability and support, ensuring they're coping with the family dynamics effectively.

content.title: Woman Wonders if It Is Ok to Settle for Mr. Almost Right
content.text:
some new neighbors moved into our beautiful neighborhood recently. this couple, who seem very nice, have gotten an adorable puppy i'll call "taffy."
taffy is now about 6 months old. they leave her in front of their house, completely alone, for most of the day and all night. from what we can see, that poor dog is never allowed inside. taffy craves affection, and we all stop to pet her whenever we go by the house, just to allay some of her loneliness and boredom.
how should we deal with this painful situation? do we dare say anything to the owners -- which will obviously cause "neighbor difficulties"? please advise. -- sally in san diego

outputs.content: Consider organizing a neighborhood meeting to discuss pet care practices and express concerns collectively. This way, it feels less confrontational and more like a community effort to improve Taffy's life, minimizing one-on-one tension with the owners.

Directly speak to the neighbors with kindness and express your concerns for Taffy. Sometimes, people don't realize the impact of their actions until someone points it out. A sincere conversation might encourage them to change their behavior.

Involve animal welfare organizations anonymously. They can assess whether Taffy’s conditions meet animal care standards without implicating you directly, preserving neighborly relations while ensuring Taffy gets the help she needs.

Respect their decisions and status as pet owners. Perhaps they have reasons we don't understand. Simply continue offering Taffy affection when you see her; after all, it's possible she is being well cared for beyond what meets the eye.

Create a neighborhood dog-walking rota. Offer to take Taffy out for some exercise and company during the day. This approach avoids confrontation, provides Taffy with companionship, and allows you to keep a positive relationship with the owners.

content.title: Alcoholic Husband's Suicide Continues to Haunt His Wife
content.text:
can you go to al-anon if you had a husband who was an alcoholic, but is dead? he committed suicide with a 5.0 blood alcohol level.
i have been a mess for the last two years. i can't sleep, can't concentrate and don't enjoy anything. i would really like to be able to talk with people who understand what living with an alcoholic is like and won't blame me for what he did, as most of his family does. but i hesitate to go to al-anon.
what can i do to get over the self-inflicted death of a man i'll never stop loving? -- hurting in houston

outputs.content: Yes, Al-Anon welcomes anyone affected by someone else's drinking, regardless of the drinker's current status. It could provide a supportive environment to share your experiences without judgment. Remember, healing is a journey and seeking help is a strength.

Consider seeking professional therapy to navigate your grief. A therapist can provide personalized support and coping strategies. It's not just about his alcoholism but also about handling the trauma and emotional fallout from his suicide.
Find a local grief support group specifically for grieving spouses. Sometimes, it's helpful to connect with others who understand the dual pain of losing a loved one to both addiction and suicide.

Start a personal project or hobby that honors his memory while allowing for healing—maybe planting a garden or volunteering. Channeling your emotions into something positive might provide a sense of purpose and comfort.

Remember that mourning isn't linear. Sometimes, stepping out of your comfort zone, like trying Al-Anon, might open unexpected paths toward healing or closure. It's okay to try something new and decide later if it's for you.

content.title: Cold Hearted Comment Turns Bedroom Into Deep Freeze
content.text:
my 12-year-old niece, "amanda," is on her cell phone constantly. she is the smartest kid i know, but she is failing her classes and has started to lie about everything. i raised her until she was 5 -- i was only 12 myself when i started -- so i am very close to her. or so i thought.
amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington

outputs.content: Consider scheduling a dedicated time each week to engage in activities Amanda enjoys, without mentioning school or phones. Building trust away from stressors could help her feel more comfortable opening up to you about her struggles.

I suggest a frank conversation with her parents. They need to be on the same page to address her behavior consistently as a team. You can offer support but ultimately it's their responsibility to set boundaries and enforce them.

Perhaps it's time to prioritize her relationship with a counselor. She might be dealing with underlying issues that she feels uncomfortable discussing with family. Professional help can offer insights and solutions beyond what family conversations can achieve.

Show her empathy and understanding rather than disappointment. Pressuring her might push her away further. Let her know you’re there unconditionally, even if she’s making mistakes. Sometimes knowing someone is in your corner can alleviate stress and encourage openness.

Maybe it's about curbing her phone usage altogether. Talk to her parents about implementing strict phone time limits or using parental controls. It might be drastic, but sometimes restrictions lead to better habits and improvements in academic performance.

content.title: Mother in Law's Scanty Clothes Get Dressing Down From Wife
content.text:
my husband, "joe," and i have been married for 12 years. i have a daughter from a previous marriage and he has a son from a previous relationship. my daughter is married and lives in another state.
my 22-year-old stepson, "junior," lives with us. he has a history of drug and alcohol abuse and has stolen from us. i recently discovered that another item of mine was missing. i told joe it has to stop -- that i can't live like a prisoner in my own home. joe will not kick junior out of the house. joe said he would leave, but that he won't put junior out on the street like a dog.
our marriage was solid until junior's problems started a year ago. i'd never ask my husband to make a choice. junior is his son. i, on the other hand, feel like a stranger in my own home. we barely speak now and have been sleeping in separate rooms. i am at a loss. abby, have you any advice? -- stranger in my own home

outputs.content: Consider setting clear, non-negotiable boundaries with Junior. Discuss with Joe the importance of a treatment program or ultimatum for Junior while ensuring your home remains a safe space for you both.
Reflect on whether Joe's unwillingness to prioritize the safety and peace of your home is an indication of deeper issues in your marriage, and consider counseling to explore these dynamics further.
Understand Joe's perspective of wanting to support his son. Offer him empathy but make it clear that your needs matter too, suggesting a family intervention for Junior to find a solution together.

Emphasize to Joe that enabling Junior isn't helping him in the long run. Encourage finding a well-structured rehabilitation program that Junior can attend, promoting both his recovery and your household stability.

Accept that Joe is choosing to support Junior regardless of the impact on your well-being. Consider your own boundaries and what steps you need to take for your happiness and security, even if it means separation.

content.title: Young Man Wanders Adrift in Sea of Confused Emotions
content.text:
i'm a 21-year-old male who feels lost and unfulfilled, and it's because i don't know what i want or deserve. i am one of three adopted children. i was the child who always needed the family support system the most. i come from a not-so-happy family, one with all its priorities centered around money. (or, more accurately, lack of money.) i never felt the love a child should feel from his family.
my problem these days is my alcohol intake. i can't stay away from beer. i drink to forget my family problems and the fact that i can't seem to get anything right.
i dropped out of college because i don't have a passion for anything or anyone. i used to have hobbies -- like writing, photography, etc. -- but the beer has taken away my motivation and creativity.
i feel i'm losing my will to keep trying. i want so badly to keep trying, but my emotions are keeping me down. i just want something new, something i can give my all to, something that won't hurt me in the future. -- what can i do?

outputs.content: Consider seeking a therapist who can help you navigate your emotions and underlying issues. Therapy offers tools to address addiction, understand yourself better, and potentially rekindle interests. Accepting professional help doesn't only support you but can be your first step towards a healthier future.

Try joining a local support group to connect with others in similar situations. Understanding that you’re not alone can be empowering, providing insights through shared experiences. This network may also introduce you to new activities, encouraging you to explore interests without alcohol's interference.

Experiment with mindfulness practices like meditation or yoga. These can ground you in the present, reducing reliance on alcohol. Regular practice might help manage anxiety, offering a new perspective on self-worth and guiding you towards discovering what truly fulfills you.

Adopt a firm rule of small daily challenges. Embrace a sober day; maybe work on a photography project or write a paragraph daily. Gradually, emotional and creative rewards might replace alcohol's temporary numbness, helping rediscover old passions and discipline.

Pack up and travel, even if it means just heading to a different city for a few weeks on a tight budget. This break could provide the new experiences you crave, potentially unveiling forgotten passions, while offering distance from current routines and struggles.

content.title: Daughter Acts Like a Winner, but Still Feels Like a Loser
content.text:
i'm a 27-year-old woman who still lives at home. i do it so i can help my mom with my five nieces and nephews. their mother passed away suddenly in 2009 at the age of 30. my mom and stepdad kept them rather than scatter them to fathers who don't appear very interested in them.
since my sister's death i have earned two degrees, entered the health care field and have lost almost 140 pounds. despite what i have accomplished, i feel i have nothing to show for myself. when i point my accomplishments out to myself, they don't seem like a heck of a lot. what can i do so i can stop feeling like a loser? -- lost in the northeast

outputs.content: Consider redefining success in terms of personal values and contributions. You've made a tremendous impact by supporting your family and pursuing education. Focusing on gratitude and self-compassion may help shift your perspective from perceived societal standards to personal fulfillment.

Perhaps speaking with a therapist could be beneficial. They might offer tools to reframe your achievements and boost your self-esteem. It's likely that societal pressures are skewing your self-perception, and professional guidance might help ground you in your true worth.

Maybe it's time to set new, personal goals outside the family and career achievements. Challenge yourself with a hobby or travel experience. Finding fulfillment in personal passions might enrich your life and give you a new sense of accomplishment.

What you're feeling isn't uncommon, given societal pressures. Keep a gratitude journal to remind yourself of daily victories, however small. This practice can reinforce positivity and help you appreciate your journey, viewing each step as an achievement.

Your accomplishments deserve celebration. Share your story in support groups or online platforms. Hearing feedback from others dealing with similar familial obligations might validate your experiences and reinforce the value of your contributions. Community can be incredibly empowering.

content.title: CON MAN HIDES NAME, ADDRESS TO DEFRAUD PEN PAL
content.text:
about a month ago, we lost our beloved pet. she had been a constant companion and friend for 13 years. i can't believe how her death has affected me. most people have a very hard time understanding that she was as much a part of my life and family as my husband and children, and i grieve for her as i would for any family member.
i feel as though i may need some sort of counseling, but i don't know where to turn. i'm having a difficult time getting on with my life. i feel heartsick and depressed. some mornings i don't even want to get out of bed.
we have other pets, and though we love them very much, none can take her place.
can you help me, please?
grief-stricken

outputs.content: Consider seeking out a pet loss support group, where you'll find others who understand the depth of your grief. Sharing experiences and finding community with people facing similar pain can offer healing and reassurance that your feelings are valid.

It's important to acknowledge that you're grieving, and that's okay. Try journaling to express and process your emotions. It might help to create a scrapbook or a memorial for your pet, celebrating the joy they brought to your life.

Pet loss is difficult, but dwelling too long can be unhealthy. Start setting small daily goals to re-engage with life. Consult a grief counselor or therapist who can guide you in balancing your emotions and moving forward productively.

Consider adopting a new pet eventually. They won't replace your lost companion, but they can bring new joy and purpose. Volunteer at an animal shelter to spend time with animals; the interactions might offer comfort and new perspective.

Focus on self-care and gradual adjustment. Engage in different activities that interest you or resume a hobby you enjoy. If you feel unresolved guilt or worry, therapy is a chance to address those feelings, but don't rush the healing process.

content.title: SUCH CHARITY IS MISDIRECTED
content.text:
i am to be married soon and have a very serious problem to face. my fiance's father is seriously ill. (he's terminal.) the doctors have just given him a period of time to live, which comes very close to our wedding date. we set our wedding date four months ago--before we knew how sick he was.
if he is called by god close to our wedding date, what is the proper etiquette with regard to our wedding? how can we handle the joy of our wedding with the sorrow of his passing, which will be mourned by my fiance's mother and the rest of his family?
please answer soon as there isn't much time. happy and sad

outputs.content: Consider postponing the wedding. With your fiancé's family grieving, a ceremony can feel inappropriate during their mourning period. Discuss with family members to gauge their emotions and come to a consensus that honors both celebration and loss.

Proceed with the wedding as planned, while incorporating a tribute to your fiancé's father. This could be a moment of silence or a small dedication, acknowledging the complexity of joy and grief intertwined.
Focus on a smaller, intimate ceremony even if the date is unchanged. This respects the mourning yet allows you to honor your commitment to one another, providing some solace amidst the sorrow.

Cancel the wedding for now out of respect for your fiancé's family. It may feel daunting, but prioritizing their emotional needs shows consideration for their grief, leaving the celebration for a more appropriate time.

Leave the decision to your fiancé's family, offering to adapt your plans based on what they feel comfortable with. This shows you prioritize their emotional well-being and are willing to share this transition phase with them respectfully.

content.title: BIGOTRY SHOULD NEVER BE TOLERATED
content.text:
my husband and i recently had five couples to our home for dinner. the dinner was delicious--everyone raved. but immediately after the dessert, one of the guests asked for a newspaper to check the movie listings.
before we knew it, four couples were putting on their coats and running out the door so they wouldn't be late for the movie. i will say in their defense that they invited my husband and me to join them, but we declined.
what do you think of such people? too sensitive in n. y.

outputs.content: Some might view this as rude; leaving abruptly after dinner suggests they value the movie over your company. However, maybe it was an honest miscommunication where they assumed you'd join. Prioritize the friendships but set clearer boundaries next time.

It sounds like these guests are fun and spontaneous, perhaps overly so. While their behavior might seem discourteous, they probably didn't mean any harm. In fast-paced environments, people often chase entertainment, sometimes forgetting hosts' feelings.

In New York, such behavior can be typical given the rushed lifestyle. Yet, it's inconsiderate not to linger longer after a host's effort. People should balance their commitments better, respecting the warmth and time someone offers by inviting them.

While this might feel like an ungrateful exit, consider it a compliment—they felt at ease to be themselves, indicating comfort in your home. Communication could've clarified plans, sparing any perceived slight and balancing expectations among friends.

Honestly, it's quite rude. Social norms generally value spending more time with those who host you. They might be well-meaning, but it reflects poorly on their understanding of social etiquette, reducing such gatherings to mere interludes between plans.

content.title: ALCOHOLIC'S PLIGHT UPSETS STRANGER
content.text:
i placed an ad in our local lincoln paper to "drive your car to any destination for a fee." this morning a lady called, wanting me to drive her to a retirement home in texas. after the price was agreed upon, i went to her apartment in lincoln.
when she met me at the door she was crying, saying she was an alcoholic --and a very sick woman--and could i please help her. the poor woman was shaking, so i suggested we call a family member as i had never seen this lady before in my life. (there is alcoholism in my family, so my heart went out to her.) she said she was 69, but she looked much older. she started shaking badly, and began looking for her bottle. (she had bottles hidden all over the place, but the ones i found were empty!) we visited for half an hour, then she fell asleep on the couch, so i called the apartment manager who turned out to be a young lady about 35. she said, "leave her alone; don't get involved. go on home."
i went home, but, abby, this poor lady has called me five times asking me to come back. part of me says, "go back and try to help her," and the other half says, "listen to the manager--don't get involved."
i feel guilty because like most people, i don't want to get involved, but i can't get this lady out of my mind. she said she has no family. what would you do in a case like this? w.f., palmyra, neb.

outputs.content: I would respect the apartment manager's advice. As someone without the expertise in dealing with addiction, getting involved might cause more harm than good. Reporting her situation to a local social service may be a more responsible step to ensure her well-being.

I would go back and offer her a ride to a local Alcoholics Anonymous meeting or a nearby rehabilitation center. Sometimes what people need is a little push and company during their first step towards recovery. It could make a difference in her life.

I believe in personal responsibility. She has already made her choice to live like this, and it isn't my problem. There's only so much you can do—everyone is ultimately responsible for their own actions and decisions, no matter how sad.

Perhaps compromise is the best approach. I would call a helpline or find a local support group and pass on their contact information to her. This way, I provide a resource without directly involving myself in a potentially draining situation.

I'd probably listen to my gut instinct and help her despite the manager's advice. Sometimes the risk of getting involved is worth it if it means potentially helping someone in need, especially when they have no one else to turn to.

content.title: KIDS IN THIRD PLACE WITH GRANDMA
content.text:
our son is 3 years old. our daughter is 5. my parents live an hour away-by car. i recently phoned and asked them to come and stay with their grandchildren for a weekend while we attend a convention in another city.
my mother immediately checked to see if the dates (two months away) were on their "rv group" weekend. since we so rarely ask them to baby-sit, and the children love "nini and papa" so much, i was hurt, and wrote and told them so.
mother wrote back, listing her priorities as follows: (1) her job. (she sells real estate.) (2) her favorite activity. (taking rv group trips with her husband, who is retired.) (3) her grandchildren.
needless to say, i engaged a baby sitter. my parents are now saying that we should understand their need for freedom. abby, they have stayed with our children overnight only once in a year and a half, when we delivered the kids- never have they driven to our home to baby-sit for the evening.
we have decided never again to ask them for anything. are we right or wrong to feel as we do? third place but no show

outputs.content: You might feel hurt, but it's important to respect their desire for independence. Not everyone's priority list aligns perfectly; they still love your children but want personal time. Consider involving them more casually without expectations to foster a stronger relationship.

It's understandable to feel disappointed, but everyone has different priorities. It might help to communicate directly with your parents to convey how much their involvement means to your family. Finding a middle ground could strengthen familial bonds.

Your feelings are valid, but consider their perspective. They worked hard to enjoy their retirement, and while they love their grandchildren, it's not wrong for them to cherish personal freedom. Perhaps re-evaluating the situation with empathy could offer peace.

You're justified in feeling overlooked. Grandparents often play active roles in children's lives, and their apparent disinterest is painful. It's fair to be less reliant on them if they consistently put personal activities above family commitments, though it might estrange further.

Cutting ties with them as grandparents seems drastic. You have a right to feel let down, but understanding their lifestyle choice doesn't diminish their love for your kids. Finding alternative support allows maintaining a relationship without imposing on their preferred lifestyle.

content.title: HALF-TRUTHS TELL THE WHOLE STORY
content.text:
i need your advice about something-sales clerks. i can't stand them! they aggravate me beyond belief. sometimes i even leave the store if they really get to me. i try not to ask for their help because when i do, they stick to me like glue until i leave the store. if i go to try something on, they will be waiting for me to tell me how good i look.
abby, when i try something on, i like to look at it alone and think about buying it, not feel like i'm pressured for time to get out of the change room. if sales clerks want to sell something, they have to give the customer space and privacy.
in the meantime, do you know of a way to tell these salespeople that their help is appreciated, but you would like to be left alone? sign me ... too much attention

outputs.content: "Hi there, I really appreciate your assistance and can tell you’re good at what you do, but I need some alone time to decide. If I need anything, I’ll be sure to ask for you specifically. Thanks!"
You could try shopping online if in-person clerks trigger you. You’ll have zero interaction with salespeople and plenty of time to deliberate your purchases in the comfort of your own home.

Consider reflecting on this. Maybe try viewing their eagerness as a positive attempt to ensure you have a good experience. They’re just doing their job. Who knows, their input may actually be valuable!
Maybe you could bring a friend along who can be your intermediary. They can engage the clerk while keeping the pressure off you, allowing you to focus on your shopping without interruption.

You could directly say, "Thanks, I appreciate the help, but I'd like to browse independently for now," and maintain distance. Often, clear communication helps set the desired boundaries without offending anyone.

content.title: MOM UPSET BY NEW PART-TIME ROLE
content.text:
during the past 10 years, i have raised four children. the last two are twins. as the school year begins, i see my babies going off to school full time. what happens now?
we can't wait until our children say their first words, take their first steps, are finally out of diapers, and then-boom, they are off to kindergarten!
i actually looked forward to their being in school all day, but now that it has happened, i am lost. i don't know what to do with myself. i ask myself if i should take up a hobby or get a job. or perhaps have another baby?
am i crazy for feeling this way? are there others out there who have felt this way? brentwood, n.y., mom

outputs.content: You're definitely not alone. Many parents experience a sense of loss when their children start school. It might be worth exploring hobbies or volunteering in the community. Finding a new purpose or routine can help fill the gap!

Maybe this is the perfect time to focus on self-care and rediscover your identity outside motherhood. Consider taking classes or pursuing interests you put on hold. You've dedicated so much time to your kids; now it's about you!

Jumping back into the workforce could bring a sense of accomplishment and purpose. It's not uncommon to feel a bit disoriented now, but finding a job might provide a structured and fulfilling daily routine.

Thinking about having another baby is natural if you feel lost without the hustle of early parenting. However, ensure it's what both you and your partner want and not just a reaction to feeling unsure or isolated.

It's okay to feel conflicted; motherhood is a big part of your identity. Seeking a community of other parents might provide support and ideas on how to navigate this phase. Sharing experiences can be incredibly validating.

content.title: 19-year-old resents house rules
content.text:
i am 18 years old and consider myself a man. i work full time, live with my parents and pay room and board. my question: shouldn't i be allowed to have my girlfriend sleep over in my room? she's 19 and my one and only girlfriend.
i believe that since i am paying for this room and am of age, i should be able to have overnight company here if i want to. my parents disagree. they think i should live by the house rules they set before i turned 18. i always respected their rules and never complained.
i love my parents and enjoy living with them, but think they should not put any restrictions on what i can do in my room as long as i am paying rent. what do you think? must i move out to avoid a hassle? this is the only thing we ever argue about. a man with little boy rules

outputs.content: Living with your parents means respecting their house rules, even if you're paying rent. It may be frustrating, but maintaining a healthy, respectful relationship with them is important. Discussing boundaries and reaching a compromise could help both sides feel heard.

If you want complete independence, moving out would allow you to set your own rules without interpersonal friction. It may be challenging financially, but it would give you the freedom to make decisions under your roof without compromise.

Consider your parents' perspective and how they feel about privacy and boundaries in their home. Initiating a mature conversation exploring their concerns could help you find middle ground, balancing respect for their rules with your need for autonomy.

Parents sometimes hold onto their control even when you're an adult, fearing change. Their reluctance might stem from wanting to preserve household norms. Perhaps showing responsibility in other areas could earn their trust to loosen restrictions on your room.

Paying rent doesn't inherently equate to shared property rights if living with family. You could consider renegotiating your financial contribution in exchange for fewer restrictions, framing it as a more balanced tenant-landlord relationship, emphasizing mutual respect.
